titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Wyoming Photograph Album, 1899
titlestmt.subtitle: Wyoming Photograph Album Ms2017-026

titlepage.subtitle:
A Collection in
Special Collections Ms2017-026

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, Va.
did.abstract: Photograph album titled "A Trip up the Sweetwater River," containing images of various scenes in Wyoming, probably around the turn of the 20th century.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Permission to publish material from the Wyoming Photograph Album must be obtained from Special Collections, Virginia Tech.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Wyoming Photograph Album, Ms2017-026, Special Collections, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, Va.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Wyoming Photograph Album was acquired by Special Collections prior to 2002.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The processing and description of the Wyoming Photograph Album commenced and was completed in August, 2017.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of a single, undated photograph album, bearing the title "A Trip up the Sweetwater River." The album includes images of a number of Wyoming scenes, probably from around the turn of the 20th century. Among the images are views of Atlantic City, Casper, Cheyenne, Douglass, Glenda, and Lewiston, Wyoming; freight teams; mines and refineries; livestock and other animals; camp life, travel, and survey teams; Ferris and Wind River Mountains; Cowley's, Bothwell's, and Schoonmaker's dams; Schoonmaker's and Goose-Egg ranches; Tom Sun's Cabin; Bothwell Ditch; Devil's Gate; Castle and Independence rocks; Continental Peak; Oregon Buttes; and Whiskey Gap.
Inserted in the album are a few snapshots of men on horseback and a photo of Wallace Coburn, apparently detached from a separate album, and dated "Great Falls, Gibson Park, 1899."

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Wallace Coburn (1872-1954) was a producer of western films and a cowboy-poet whose work was collected in Rhymes from the Round-up Camp (1899), illustrated by Coburn's personal friend, Charles M. Russell. Coburn was also the father of film actor and stuntwoman Dorothy Coburn.
